I.  INTRODUCTION 
 
1.  The Association of Southeast Asian Nations (ASEAN) member states inaugurated the 
ASEAN Economic Community (AEC) along with the AEC Blueprint 20251 at the Kuala Lumpur 
Leaders’ Summit in November 2015—8 years after the endorsement of the first AEC Blueprint 
2015. The AEC Blueprint 2015 has acted as the master plan in guiding the region’s process of 
market integration and competiveness improvement. It was built on four interrelated pillars: (i) a 
single market and production base that enjoys the free flow of goods, services, investment, 
capital,  and  skilled  labor;  (ii)  a  competitive  economic  region;  (iii)  equitable  economic 
development; and (iv) integration with the global economy.2  
 
2.  The proposed regional technical assistance (TA) is included in the Regional Cooperation 
and Integration Pipeline for Southeast Asia, 2015–2017 and is consistent with the priorities of 
strengthening regional cooperation and integration and competitiveness in the following country 
partnership strategies: 3 2014–2018 for Cambodia; 2012–2016 for the Lao People's Democratic 
Republic (Lao PDR); 2011–2016 for the Philippines; and 2016–2019 for Indonesia.4 It supports 
the Midterm Review of Strategy 2020.5 In response to requests from the governments, the Asian 
Development  Bank  (ADB)  fielded  AEC  assessment  consultation  missions  to  Cambodia, 
Indonesia, the Lao PDR, and the Philippines from October 2015 to July 2016. The missions met 
with country counterparts and discussed (i) the status and challenges faced in implementing the 
AEC  commitments;  (ii)  the  needs,  broad  scope,  costs,  implementation  arrangements;  and  
(iii) the technical support required. Each country confirmed that AEC is a high priority and 
confirmed their interest in participating in the TA. Regular consultations would be maintained 
during TA preparation and implementation. The design and monitoring framework is outlined in 
Appendix 1. 
 
II.  ISSUES 
 
3.  By the AEC inauguration in November 2015, the ASEAN member states (AMSs) had 
eliminated most intra-ASEAN tariffs and had partially established the ASEAN trade repository to 
document trade and customs laws, and procedures to improve transparency. The AMSs signed 
the ASEAN Comprehensive Investment Agreement with the objective of building a regional 
investment area. Under the ASEAN Framework Agreement on Services, services liberalization 
commitments, representing a coverage ratio from 70% to 84% of total services subsectors, were 
concluded. To promote the movement of skilled labor, eight mutual recognition arrangements on 
professional services were signed.6 By the end of 2015, the majority of AMSs had passed 
competition laws to enhance market efficiency and provide firms equal opportunities to compete 
in the ASEAN markets. Several countries also introduced good regulatory practices and started 
to  conduct  regulatory  impact  assessments  (RIAs),  albeit  at  varying  scales  and  scopes. 
                                                
1  ASEAN. 2015. ASEAN Economic Community Blueprint 2025. Jakarta. 
  http://www.asean.org/storage/images/2015/November/aec-page/AEC-Blueprint-2025-FINAL.pdf   
2  Under Blueprint 2025, the four pillars were renamed as “five characteristics,” i.e.,(i) highly integrated and cohesive 
economy; (ii) competitive, innovative, and dynamic ASEAN; (iii) enhanced connectivity and sectoral development; 
(iv)  resilient,  inclusive,  people-oriented  ASEAN;  and  (v) global  ASEAN.  Reforms  in each  characteristic  are 
generally mapped to the original pillars under Blueprint 2015.

2   
Notwithstanding these positive developments, AEC implementation is far from complete.7 With 
easier reforms already completed, AEC under Blueprint 2025 will face more challenges by 
moving  into  more  difficult  reforms,  such  as  regulatory  harmonization  and  convergence. 
Addressing these will require a combination of policy reforms and practical implementation 
efforts. Progress in AEC implementation also varies, with Singapore, Malaysia, and Thailand as 
the  most  advanced;  followed  by  Indonesia,  the  Philippines,  and  Viet  Nam.  While  making 
significant headway, Cambodia, the Lao PDR, and Myanmar still have a lot to do to catch up. 
Bridging these gaps remains a major challenge, but it is crucial for AEC to be able to benefit all 
countries. 
 
4.  Restricted  regional  movement.  The  regional  movement  of  goods,  services, 
investment, capital, and skilled labor are still subject to many restrictions, which are often 
embedded in the national policies, rules, and regulations. This hinders AEC benefits, especially 
further growth of regional trade and investment, in four ways. First, the services trade in ASEAN 
is far more restrictive than the global average and more than in East Asia, among which the 
Philippines has the most restrictive policy regime with a services trade restrictive index of 53, 
followed by Indonesia at 50.8 Challenges  increase when AEC commitments require amending 
domestic laws or, in some cases, national constitutions.9 The movement of skilled labor is 
subject to many domestic constraints, such as labor markets tests to determine no qualified 
nationals available to fill those positions, permits, and visa requirements. Second, ambitions to 
establish  open  and transparent  investment  regimes  are  thwarted  by  the  list  of  investment 
restrictions that countries maintain and the wide use of investment incentive schemes. Third, 
progress  has  been  slow  in  rationalizing  nontariff  measures,  with  their  numbers  increasing 
almost four-fold between 2000 and 2015 as tariffs got lower.10 Fourth, the seamless movement 
of capital is difficult, partly due to varying degrees of capital market development within the 
region as well as the policy of AMSs to maintain domestic financial stability. Cambodia and the 
Lao PDR are not members of the International Organization of Securities Commissions. Policy 
makers in some ASEAN countries face an important task of formulating practical actions by 
assessing and comprehending the implications of AEC integration (especially that of selected 
services sectors, e.g., tourism, education, health care, logistics, civil aviation, shipping, and 
investment)  in  national  economies  as  well  as  communicating  with  stakeholders  to  gauge 
support for reforms.  
 
5.  Complex and inefficient regulatory regimes. An important element of AEC is for each 
AMS to introduce competition laws as an integral component of policy aimed at ensuring fair 
competition, following a set of common ASEAN guidelines. Another key AEC target is for AMSs 
to align and harmonize their regulatory frameworks. Until 2014, only five AMSs had enacted 
competition laws, with the Philippines and the Lao PDR enacting competition laws in 2015. The 
Philippines established the Philippine Competition Commission (PCC) in 2016. Cambodia plans

Philippines, and Viet Nam in 2016. In spite of the different pace in implementation, all countries have gaps in 
meeting AEC commitments. The assessments found more time and consultations are needed to outline the scope 
of assistance for Myanmar and Viet Nam; therefore, they will be included in the next regional TA.

10  The Economic Research Institute for ASEAN and East Asia, in collaboration with the United Nations Conference

3 
to enact its Competition Law by the end of 2016. Cambodia and the Lao PDR have introduced a 
RIA process and the Philippines has started RIA pilots, but this is only the first step. Many 
daunting challenges remain in implementing competition policies and regulatory reforms in 
ASEAN—both of which are difficult to reform because they are national in application.   
 
6.  Monitoring progress. Systematic monitoring of the AEC implementation progress is 
challenging. Under Blueprint 2015, AEC implementation was addressed through a strategic 
schedule, covering over 500 individual actions. A scorecard was used to track AEC measures 
implemented from 2008. However, only an aggregated figure across all AMSs is available from 
2011,  and  it  is  difficult  to  ascertain  real  progress.  Under  Blueprint  2025,  monitoring  and 
evaluation will be enhanced, with the AEC Council as the principal body overseeing overall 
implementation. In August 2016, the 48th ASEAN Economic Ministers endorsed a few key 
sectoral strategic action plans (SAPs) and work plans covering goods, services, investment, and 
competition. AMS governments need to work closely with the AEC Council and its committees 
to translate Blueprint 2025 and individual SAPs into national plans.11 In this process, additional 
country support is necessary to formulate national plans and strengthen national monitoring.   
 
7.  ADB has had a long engagement with AMSs on regional integration both at the ASEAN 
level and in various subregional initiatives as the lead development partner on (i) TA and grant 
projects covering trade (facilitation); (ii) national policy-based loans promoting economic policy 
reforms and capacity development, such as competition policy and RIAs; and (iii) knowledge 
products  on  ASEAN  integration,  the  Greater  Mekong  Subregion,  the  Brunei  Darussalam–
Indonesia–Malaysia–Philippines  East  ASEAN  Growth  Area,  and  the  Indonesia–Malaysia–
Thailand Growth Triangle.12 These interventions have generated the technical knowledge, built 
up collaboration between ADB and the governments, and laid the basis for consolidated support 
in AEC integration. The TA support  will help plan and prepare the ASEAN-wide programmatic 
approach for AEC support program by developing national agendas for policy dialogues across 
high-impact areas including trade, services, investments, competition policy, and RIAs with the 
respective  governments;  supporting  capacity  development;  and  strengthening  country-level 
monitoring of AEC. 
 
III.  THE PROPOSED CAPACITY DEVELOPMENT TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
 
8.  The TA impact is a more dynamic and competitive region with a single market and 
production base achieved, which is aligned with Blueprint 2025 (footnote 1). The TA outcome is 
implementation of the AEC commitments in priority areas improved.

B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
 
9.  This TA will have three outputs, mainly covering activities falling under characteristics 1 
and  2  of  Blueprint  2025  (footnote  2).  These  outputs  will  provide  the  analyses  and 
recommendations  that can  potentially  feed  into  the  preparation  of  a regional  ASEAN-wide 
programmatic  approach  of  an  AEC  support  program.  During  implementation,  unforeseen 
changes in the domestic political situations in participating governments may alter their priorities 
with regard to their earlier commitments, and the TA will need to adapt accordingly. Lack of 
participation and coordination among key agencies may also delay AEC implementation and 
reforms. 
 
10.  Output 1: Action plans and/or road maps to participate in the ASEAN Economic 
Community prepared. Based on the findings of the AEC assessments and in response to the 
requests from countries, this output will support the preparation of diagnostics and/or technical 
reports, leading to the drafting or strengthening of time-bound action plans and/or road maps 
under national agendas. This includes improving the trade and investment environment, and 
strengthening sector competitiveness (e.g., to gain access to and benefit from regional markets) 
to enable countries to better utilize AEC’s opportunities and to inform the preparation of policy-
based lending programs for AEC.    
 
11.  Output 2: Capacity to implement the ASEAN Economic Community commitments 
in  priority  areas  developed.  This  output  will  support  AEC  initiatives,  which  have  been 
identified  through  country  consultations  and  AEC  assessments  on  (i)  trade  in  services;  
(ii) investments; (iii) skilled labor; and (iv) competition law and policies, including RIAs. It will 
also support the action plans prepared under output 1. Under items (i) and (ii), the TA will 
finance selective technical and/or impact studies and capacity-building activities on trade in 
services and the investment regimes in Cambodia, Indonesia, and the Philippines.13 These 
analytical studies will support the governments to pursue pro-competitive reforms to improve 
transparency and lower transaction costs. Under item (iii), the TA will support mapping of the 
process of selective mutual recognition arrangements in Cambodia, Indonesia, the Lao PDR, 
and  the  Philippines  to  identify  implementation  constraints,  such  as  permits  and  visa 
requirements. Under item (iv), the TA will support the Philippines to implement the competition 
law  and  conduct  RIAs.  The TA  will  support the  newly  established  PCC  to  implement the 
Philippine Competition Law. The TA will also support the Government of the Philippines to step 
up efforts to promote good regulatory practices by conducting additional pilot RIAs, and to make 
the National Economic and Development Authority the gatekeeper of a national rollout of RIAs 
across all agencies. Support for RIAs in Cambodia and the Lao PDR are provided by ongoing 
ADB assistance.14  
 
12.  Output  3:  Monitoring  and  evaluation  of  ASEAN  Economic  Community 
implementation  at  the  country  level  strengthened.  Under  Blueprint  2025,  the  ASEAN 
Secretariat will monitor and track the implementation of SAPs through an enhanced monitoring 
framework, which is still under discussion. At the request of countries, this output will support 
the governments to strengthen their own monitoring and evaluation systems at the country

and/or sectoral level by helping identify national indicators and conducting staff training, and 
improving the timeliness and transparency of AEC implementation. 
 
C.  Cost and Financing  
 
13.  The TA is estimated to cost $2 million, which will be financed on a grant basis by ADB’s 
Technical Assistance Special Fund (TASF-other sources). 
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
 
14.  ADB  will  be  the  executing  agency,  and  its  Southeast  Asia  Department  will  be 
responsible for the administration and supervision of the TA.15 The TA will commence  on  
1 December 2016 and be completed by 31 December 2020. In the Philippines, the Department 
of Finance will coordinate TA activities. The National Economic and Development Authority, the 
Department of Trade and Industry, the PCC, and the Professional Regulation Commission will 
participate in TA activities. In Indonesia, the Coordinating Ministry for Economic Affairs will 
coordinate TA activities, while the Ministry of Trade, Indonesia Investment Coordinating Board 
(BKPM),  the  Ministry  of  Manpower  (Professional  Certification  Authority),  and  the  National 
Development Planning Agency (BAPPENAS) will participate in TA activities. In Cambodia, the 
Ministry of Commerce will coordinate TA activities, and the Ministry of Industry and Handicrafts 
will participate in the TA activities. In the Lao PDR, the Ministry of Industry and Commerce will 
coordinate TA activities, and the Ministry of Planning and Investment will participate in TA 
activities. In all countries, the coordinating agencies will also be responsible for disseminating 
information  and  coordinating  the  involvement  of  other  agencies.  In  each  country,  the 
government counterpart agencies are expected to provide office space, and a core team, led by 
a senior official in each participating agency, to guide and work with the consultants and ADB.  
  
15.  One  consulting  firm  (4  international  consultants,  24  person-months;  18  national 
consultants, 39 person-months) will be engaged using the quality- and cost-based selection 
method (90:10 ratio, simplified technical proposal) to provide services on strategy development, 
impact  studies,  and  monitoring  and  evaluation.  Individual  consultants  (5  international,  
28 person-months; 6 national, 40 person-months) will be engaged to provide services related to 
competition policy and RIA as these areas are highly specialized and the tasks are more 
suitable for being carried out by individuals independently. ADB will engage the consultants in 
accordance with the Guidelines on the Use of Consultants (2013, as amended from time to 
time).  The  TA  proceeds  will  be  disbursed  in  accordance  with  the  Technical  Assistance 
Disbursement Handbook (2010, as amended from time to time). The consultants under the firm 
contract will submit the following to ADB and TA participating agencies: (i) an inception report,  
(ii) progress reports, and (iii) a draft final report and a final report. The individual consultants will 
submit technical reports as outlined in the terms of reference. 
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION  
 
16.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the 
provision of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $2,000,000 on a grant basis 
for Support to the Association of Southeast Asian Nations Economic Community, and hereby 
reports this action to the Board.  
                                                
15  Coordination within ADB, including with the Sustainable Development and Climate Change Department and the       
Economic Cooperation and Research Department, will be maintained throughout TA implementation.

Guidelines on the Use of Consultants (2013, as amended from time to time) of the Asian 
Development Bank (ADB). The consulting firm will be engaged using the quality- and cost-
based  selection method  (90:10  ratio)  to  provide  services  on  strategy development,  impact 
studies, and monitoring and evaluation. The individual consultants will provide services related 
to competition policy and regulatory impact assessments (RIAs).

1.  Strategy Development Experts (1 international, 6 person-months; 4 national,  
6 person-months total) 
 
2.  The experts will support the achievement of output 1. They will support diagnostics and 
technical reports for preparing action plans and/or road maps to more effectively implement the 
ASEAN Economic Community (AEC) (focusing on Cambodia and the Lao People's Democratic 
Republic [Lao PDR], but can also cover the Philippines and Indonesia) to help plan and prepare 
the  programmatic  approach  of  AEC  policy-based  lending.  The  experts  will  undertake  the 
following tasks, in collaboration with government counterparts and the ADB team: (i) plan and 
prepare technical reports on areas critical for the country’s effective participation in and to 
benefit from the AEC; (ii) identify important policy issues; (iii) make recommendations on policy 
choices; and (iv) assist consensus workshops, trainings, and capacity-building events.

have at least 10 years of professional experience working in strategy development, preferably in 
the Association of Southeast Asian Nations (ASEAN) region covering economic policy and 
institutional development. The national experts should have  a degree in economics, or an 
equivalent field, and have prior professional experience in research and strategy development, 
covering policy and institutional development. Prior experience with AEC is an advantage.  
 
2.  Services  Sector  Experts  (1  international,  8  person-months;  3  national,  
8 person-months total)

diagnostics, policy development, and capacity upgrades to implement AEC targets on services 
in Cambodia, Indonesia, and the Philippines. They will be responsible for the following:

going forward, in particular the policy actions and/or milestones.
